database package#

Submodules#

database.database_commands module#

This module contains all functions with logic to interact with the database finances.db. This is the only module which accesses the database. There are six tables; expenses, income, categories, sources, budget and goals.

database.database_commands.create_tables()[source]#

This function creates all tables in the database if they don’t exist and calls function to populate tables.

Returns:

None

database.database_commands.enter_budget(category_id, amount, term)[source]#

This function enters a new budget assigned to a category

Parameters:

  • category_id – primary key in categories table

  • amount – new budget amount

  • term – “weekly”, “monthly”, or “annual”

Returns:

None

database.database_commands.enter_category(new_cat, table)[source]#

This function enters a new category in a table.

Parameters:

  • new_cat – new expense category or income source

  • table – expenses or sources table in database

Returns:

None

database.database_commands.enter_goal(goal, amount, term)[source]#

This function enters a new goal into the goals table

Parameters:

  • goal – ‘budget’, ‘net income’ or ‘gross income’

  • amount – amount of money in goal

  • term – ‘weekly’, ‘monthly’ or ‘annual’

Returns:

None

database.database_commands.fetch_all(command)[source]#

This function fetches data from one or more rows in the database.

Parameters:

  • input – SQLite command

  • args – arguments for SQLite command

Returns:

data from one or more rows

Return type:

List of tuples

database.database_commands.fetch_all_with_args(string, args)[source]#

This function fetches data from one or more rows in the database which match selected arguments.

Parameters:

  • input – SQLite command

  • args – arguments for SQLite command

Returns:

data from one or more rows

Return type:

List of tuples

database.database_commands.fetch_one(command)[source]#

This function fetches data from one row in the database.

Parameters:

  • input – SQLite command

  • args – arguments for SQLite command

Returns:

data from one row

Return type:

tuple

database.database_commands.fetch_one_with_args(string, args)[source]#

This function fetches data from one row in the database by selected arguments.

Parameters:

  • input – SQLite command

  • args – arguments for SQLite command

Returns:

data from one row

Return type:

tuple

database.database_commands.get_category_from_budget(budget_id)[source]#

This function gets the category description, for a budget set by category, from its budget id number

Parameters:

budget_id – budget primary key which is category foreign key

Returns:

category description or None

Return type:

str or None

database.database_commands.get_category_from_id(id_, table)[source]#

This function gets the description of an expenses category or income source from its id number

Parameters:

  • category_id – primary key in table

  • table – ‘categories’ or ‘sources’

Returns:

category

Return type:

str

database.database_commands.get_cursor()[source]#

This function catches any errors when connecting to the database and creates a cursor.

Returns:

cursor

Return type:

cursor

database.database_commands.get_expenses_by_date(days_list)[source]#

This function gets expenses for each day in a list.

Parameters:

days_list – list of dates

Returns:

list of rows from expenses table

Return type:

list of tuples

database.database_commands.get_expenses_date_amount(category_id)[source]#

This function gets the date and amount of expenses from a chosen category.

Parameters:

category_id – foreign key in expenses table

Returns:

date and amount of expenses

Return type:

list of tuples

database.database_commands.get_goal(goal, term)[source]#

This function gets a goal amount from the goals table from its description and term

Parameters:

  • goal – ‘budget’, ‘net income’ or ‘gross income’

  • term – ‘weekly’, ‘monthly’ or ‘annual’

Returns:

goal amount or None

Return type:

float or None

database.database_commands.get_income_by_date(days_list)[source]#

This function gets income for each day in a list

Parameters:

days_list – list of days

Returns:

list of rows from income table

Return type:

list of tuples

database.database_commands.get_joined_rows(table)[source]#

This function gets all rows from a joined table.

Parameters:

table – table name

Returns:

all rows from joined table

Return type:

list of tuples

database.database_commands.get_row_list(table)[source]#

This function gets a list of all the rows in a table.

Parameters:

table – table in database

Returns:

all rows

Return type:

list

database.database_commands.get_rows(year_month, table)[source]#

This function gets all rows from a table and appends rows to a list where the date they were entered matches a selected month.

Parameters:

year_month – YYYY-MM

Returns:

all rows which match year_month from table

Return type:

list of tuples

database.database_commands.insert_budget(category_id, budget)[source]#

This function enters a new budget assigned to a category.

Parameters:

  • category_id – primary key in categories table

  • budget – tuple containing (amount, term)

Returns:

None

database.database_commands.insert_data(string, args)[source]#

This function inserts data into the database.

Parameters:

  • string – SQLite command

  • args – tuple with arguments for command

Returns:

None

database.database_commands.insert_many(command)[source]#

This function inserts a list of data into the database.

Parameters:

command – tuple containing (str, list)

Returns:

None

database.database_commands.populate_tables()[source]#

This function checks if there is any data in the expenses table and if not it populates all tables with dummy data for testing.

Returns:

None

database.database_commands.update_category(table, id_, update)[source]#

This function updates a description for an expense category or an income source.

Parameters:

  • table – ‘categories’ or ‘sources’

  • cat_id – primary key id number

Returns:

None

database.populate_finances_db module#

This module adds dummy data to the tables in the database for testing purposes.

database.populate_finances_db.populate_tables()[source]#

This function populates tables in database with dummy data.

Returns:

None
